options.text: increase the water permeability of the proximal tubules
increase the permeability of the peritubular capillaries
increase the capillary permeability in the glomerulus
regulate the filtration slits
increase the water permeability of the collecting tubules

questions.text: The autonomic innervation of the urinary bladder involves:

options.text: the activation of nicotinic acetyl-choline receptors by parasympathetic activity
the activation of beta-2 receptors by sympathetic activity
sympathetic nerves exert presynaptic inhibition on parasympathetic terminals
the activation of alfa-1 receptors by sympathetic activity
the activation of muscarinic acetyl-choline receptors by parasympathetic activity

metadata.notes: Bladder innervation - topic 48: Renal concentration/dilution (related to bladder function)

questions.text: Given the following data for inulin and substance "X" which of the following would explain the renal handling of substance "X" Inulin concentration in the urine 200 mg/100 ml, Inulin concentration in the plasma 2 mg/100 ml, Concentration in the urine for "X" substance 15 mg/100 ml, Concentration in the plasma for "X" substance 1.5 mg/100 ml

options.text: "X" is freely filtered and additionally secreted
"X" is freely filtered but partially reabsorbed
"X" is freely filtered but neither secreted nor reabsorbed

questions.text: Na+ can be transported across the luminal membrane of renal tubular cells by

options.text: diffusion through Na+ channels
co-transport with organic solutes
counter transport for H+
the Na-K ATPase

metadata.notes: Na+ transport mechanisms - topic 46: Tubular reabsorption

questions.text: A healthy individual on a diet high in potassium exhibits increased potassium excretion. The major cause of this increased renal secretion of potassium is

options.text: decreased reabsorption of potassium by the tubule and collecting duct
increased secretion of potassium by the distal tubule and collecting duct
decreased aldosterone secretion
increased GFR
decreased reabsorption of potassium by the proximal tubule

options.text: their oncotic pressure is unusually low
they are discontinuous capillaries
their intracapillary pressure is unusually high
they are fenestrated capillaries
they are highly permeable to proteins

sodium
amino acids
glucose
